communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. for a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

div.head: The Financial Stringency in Egypt
div.p: The scarcity of gold which again made itself felt last month was not nearly so acute as that experienced a few weeks previously, but, on the other hand, was much more unexpected. An insufficency of gold for currency requirements is no new phenomenon in this country and will, undoubtedly, continue to occur from time to time owing to the fact that any sudden and unexpected demand for gold can only be met by fresh inmports from Europe. The position in October was declared by people who know the country well as being the worst for many years, and the general opinion was that, after the heavy importations of gold, a similar situation could not possibly occur again this season. Events have proved the inaccuracy of these opinions, for during December there was a renewed gold famine, much less acute than its predessor it is true, but which at the same time made itself somewhat severely felt, as the exchange quotations show. On Saturday the 1st December banks' buying price of cheque on London was quoted at 97 to 97 whilst on the following Monday it went down to 97 and later in the week to 96 the average of the month being a shade under 97. Although other instances might be quoted, we will content to ourselves by mentioning merely the case of a certain native who, at the present moment, is reputed to have I.E. 20,000 (20,512) in National Bank of Egypt notes hidden in his house in one of the villages. The owner will not lend this money-more especially as it is against the Mohamedan religion to receive interest-neither will he employ it in any way until a favourable oppurtunity for the purchase of land occurs.

div.head: Penny Postage
div.p: The postage on letters for British North Borneo has been reduced and fixed at 5 milliemes for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.

div.head: A Love Tragedy
div.p: The Beni-Sogef Criminal Court has sentenced Awad Mohamed Mahdi to one year's imprisonment for the murder of Assaad Eft. Saleh who had had clandestine relations with Awad' fiancée.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: No fresh cases of plague are reported in to-day Yesterday's bulletin recorded the admission into hospital of the daughter of a Greek baker who has a shop in Haret Okelle Limoun. The case is bubonio.

div.head: Navigation on the Nile.
div.p: In connection with the Baneb Barrage works, a sadd is being constructed near the western bank, about one kilometre north of the town of Esneb. Boats of all kinds navigating the river should pass to the east of the red lights fixed on the western side.

div.head: Railway Robbery.
div.p: On Saturday evening, while train No. 670, on the Delta Light Railway, was between the stations of Borwah and Meballot Marhoom, a travelling cash case, containing upwards of £200, was stolen from the van. The omdebs of the two villages were advised and a search party of railway officials immediately set out from Tantah.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: ( FROM OUR THEATRICAL CORRESPONDENT: )

"La Fille du Regiment" is as distinot a change as possible after two tew Mazgènets, Meyerbeer, and the other productions we have had so far. It is rather a delightful change, too; charming light must be known, and plenty of dialogue and acting. Mlle Charpentier and M. Darand (the sergeant) were quite good, always correct and with plenty of life as far as singing went; and they acted extremely well, better than they sang, I confess: Mlle Char, pentier looked enchantingly pretty, more so in her fashionable dress if possible that as the Vivandière ; and the sergeant was finely made up. M. Monteox had the part of Topio, and for once be sang in tone, but his voice is most distasteful, hopelessly affected, and entirely falsetto in the high notes.

The chorus were much as usual, but why do they look so deplorably stolid ! And do all French soldiers of the period wear those quaint American-striped trousers ? I rather wished they would black their faces and try a "coon" song. An elaborate ballet Wowed the opera, I confess I only ondored of it. I don't profess to understand ballet. It seemed except for Mlle Deliny, to consist in a species of swimming lessons--at least as far as the arms were concerned. Doubtless every gesture has its cabalistio meaning for the initiated. The music, by one Délibes, was rather pretty, with plenty of violine, floter, and French bora (which made one think of togs from Wagnerand that was nice).

With regard to fortbooming performances, "L'Afriesine" and "Messaline" are being "studied". I asked about places. That is always a ground of complaint for those who do not buy seats for the season, and who really want to hear opera, and not their neighbours' opinions on Bourse questions. Seats on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday are practically unobtainable, but on Fridays there are plenty as the abonnement is only partial. When will the worthy managers understand that the whole reality of the opera and theatre is annihilated by that absurd "abonnement" system! It has no single saving merit: even the regularity of the receipts is fatal to the acting and singing, as no real effort or risk is involved : an empty house represents as much money-and far less noise-than a full house. That is perhaps a merit to a few keen listeners.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: The opera season at the above theatre, thus far, has proved one of the best for several years. Each production has been well staged, and the artistes concerned are, for the most part, evenly balanced, --a very great assistance to the general success of any theatrical representation, whether dramatic or operatie. Saturday's performance of "Mefistofele" was certainly the most perfect of this opera. Signor Carlo Walter was in fine form, and his splendid voice was heard to great advantage. Sigoor Walter's histrioni ability is well known, but his Mephisto undoubtedly one of his best, and at the same time one of the most difficult roles. His impersonation is worthy of more than a passing comment, showing, as it does, most careful study, & commendable attention to the minutest detaile, a perfect picture of devilry and music, -a strange combination, perhaps, but one necessary in the present instances; in fine, an artistio performance worthy of Signor Walter.

Signor Agerbi as Paust appeared tired, and sang occasionally rather out of tune. His performance, however, was an excellent one Signora De Lerms was in perfect voice and sang admirably throughout the opera. We preferred her appearance in the second part as a brunette; why do the powers that be insist on a blonde Marguerite?

The other characters were well supported, and the orchestra worked splendidly. By the way, can nothing be done to prevent the discordant tootling and scraping indalgel in by the orchestra before each act ? Such noises cannot be intended for tuning, and they most jar on the sensitive ears of many patrons of the theatre.

div.head:
M.P's. PEREGRINATIONS.
MR. ROBERTSON VISITS DENISHWAI.
div.p: Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., has been touring in the Gharbieh province. On Saturday night the M.P. was entertained by the Omdeb of Borwah. Our Shebin el Kom Correspondent, telegraphing this morning, says :- Rumours are current here that Mr. Robertson, M.P., paid a visit to the village of Denishwai yesterday. He has also visited this town.

The journeys of Mr. Robertson are being followed with great interest by the Nationalist Press, and with such detail that one might imagine that this gentleman was being escorted throughout Egypt by a phalanx of Nationalist journalists.

"Al Ahram" remarks: We are glad to see that Mr. Robertson is engaged in inspecting many native localities and departments and taking down in his note-book all that he can gather of the circumstances of the natives. This may be useful to this country later on. We have been informed that this member of Parliament refused to see some AngloEgyptian Government officials and refrained from seeing some other persons, whose object was only to serve the interests of the Occupation.

"Al Watan," the Coptic organ, remarks :The Islamic newepaper world has welcomed Mr. J. MR bertson, M.P., with such enthusiasm that some of our contemporaries seemed on the point of hailing him as the deliverer of Egypt and the defender of Islam. Yet this gentleman's views are utterly divergent from the native way of thinking. Mr. Robertson's friends in Egypt are persons in favour of religious instructior, while he is well known to be antagonistic to all creeds. He was a friend of Bradlaugh, the notorious Atheist, and he assisted him in editing a journal whose object was the promotion of Free Thought. He is one of the members of the committee of the Rationalist Press Association together with Hoxley, Tyndall, and Haeckel, who are among those European savants who deny revealed religion. He is the author of many works dealing with liberty of thought, i.e., the denial of taith and the fictions of religious peoples' belief. Yet the leaders of Islam in Egypt have nevertheless chosen Mr. Robertson, of all people in the world, as their sincere friend, for they consider him as the man with the truest ideas! Is not this a carious anomaly?
"Al Lewa," of yesterday's date, gives the following account of Mr. Robertson's progress in the provinces :-

News comes from the Bebera that Mr. J. "M. Robertson one of the commissions composed of Liberal members of the British Parliament who are studying the condition of Egypt, arrived at Itay-el-Baroud on Friday, where he was welcomed by a number of omdehs and notables of the Mondirieh who happened to be gathered at the station. The Markaz Mamoar introduced the best known among them to Mr. Robertson, who shook hands with the natives and expressed pleasure at meeting them. His object in coming, he said was to travel through the provinces and study the manner of living of the fellaheen. Mr. Robertson, who was accompanied by Abd ElHamid Ammar, proceeded to Nahiel Biban, where he was received as a guest by the Ammar family. The natives evince their I pleasure at seeing Mr. Robertson, knowing the object he has in view.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA KAMEL.
STILL ANOTHER INTERVIEW.
div.p: A Havas telegram from Paris states that Mastapha Kamel, in an interview with a representative of the "Temps," said that Egypt was ripe for liberty and not resigned to suffering.

"Al Lewa's" Paris correspondent telegraphs that the "Temps" published on Saturday Mustapha Pasba Kamel's declarations in regard to British policy and aims in Egypt. Kamel Pasba pointed out that no agreement was possible between the Egyptians and the English so long as the latter adopted the same policy.

div.head: TURKEY AND EGYPT.
div.p: The statement contained in Constantinople telegrams to the Vienna Press that the station in Egypt is causing preoccupation on the part of Yildiz Kiosk and the Porte is unfounded. Such reports are spread by interested parties who desire to disturb the relations of Great Britain and Turkey. Equally mischievous is the further statement regarding British attacks on the position of Mukhtar Pasha, the Porte's High Commissioner, whose status, as is already known, the British and Egyptian Governments decline to recognise officially.

div.head: BANK OF ABYSSINIA.
div.p: A persistent report is current in Cairo that Mr. MacGillivray, Governor of the Bank of Abyssinia, will not return to Addis Abeba, but will shortly open an important exchange business in the capital. We have reason to believe that there is some truth in this report.

div.head: THE NEW CAIRO BOURSE.
div.p: A report is current to the effect that H. H. the Khedive has offered to lease at a reasonable figure 1,000 metres of the land be has recently purobased from the German community, opposite the Hotel d'Angleterre, Cairo, for the purpose of the new Boarse, the cost of building which he is so willing to defray and to charge a rent for the same.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: The Egyptian Estates, Limited, has under its agreement given formal notice to Mr. Salamone Conegliano, the tenant of the Alhambhra Theatre at Alexandria, to quit in six months' time. This step has been decided on owing to important developments in property in that district of the city.

div.head: L'EPARGNE IMMOBILIERE LIMITED
div.p: The statutory meeting of the above company was held on Saturday at their offices, 24, Sbaris el Maghraby, Cairo, the president, Mr. Joseph Vaast, presiding.

After the report had been read and approved, it was unanimously decided to increase the capital of the company to £800,000 by the issue of 175,000 new shares of £4 each, and full power was given to the directors to dispose of this additional capital to the best interests of the company.

Mr. Boutigny gave a short resumé of the doings and intentions of the company, and among other things, mentioned that the company bad bought 80,000 metres of land on Ghezireb Island on very exceptional conditions, and this land will be resold with facilities of payment, extending over 30 years. There are 61 lots, and already 10 have been sold : it is expected that the remainder will be disposed of in two months. This arrangement will prove most advantageous for the buyers as well as for the company, who will make a profit of about £160,000. The company have also concluded other transactions from which large profits will be derived.
The company are buying land and paying for same in shares of the new issue, and a large portion of this new issue has already been placed in this manner.
The shareholders will certainly have every reason to congratulate themselves at the end of the financial year.

div.head:
50 MILLIONAIRES FOR EGYPT.
RECORD PASSENGER LISTS
div.p: The Cunard liner Caronia and the White Star liner Cardio. which left New York on the 5th inst. for Alexandria, are bringing no less than fifty millionaires to Egypt. They have only first class passengers on board from nearly all the principal cities in the United States. None of the passengers are paying less than £280 each for the trip

The Cedrio and Caronis have the largest number of persons on board bound for Egypt that over lett New York at one time. In the office 28 of all the big steamship companies in New York it was asserted that an anosgally largo exodus to Egypt and Southern Italy is expected this winter. In the last few years, Egypt has been making great inroads on the mid winter Italian tourist traffic.

Among the prominent New Yorkers on board the Cedrio are: Mr. and Mrs. W. P. Stafford, Mr, and Mrs. J. William Beekman, Dr. and Mrs. R. . Derby, Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Potter, Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, Mr. H. W. Cannon, Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Guthrie, Mr. and Mrs. T. P. Pisko, Me. C. W. Leavitt, Jr., Mr. C. D. Paller, Captain H. J. Hoehler, U.S. A., and Mr. Hoebler, Mr. and Mrs. George Gifford, Mr. Frederick Gebhardt, Mrs. Frederick Neilson, Mt. P. N. Doubleday and Mr. Henry Clark.

On the Caronia are: Mr. Elwin C. Atkinson, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Aldrich, Dr. Edward P: Brewer, Mr. George K. Baker, Mirg Helen Collamore, Mr. Aaron M. Crane, Mr. W. F. Doty, Amerióan Consul at Tabriz, Persia ; Mr. Henry T. Parrar, Mr. and Mrs. Hagh A. Marray, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Moffitt, Dr. and Mrs. M. Loeb, Mrs. Pierre Lorillard, Mr. and Mrs. Horace L. Hotohkiss, Mr. Albert G. C. Hsbn, Mr. George A. Ganther, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred T. White, Mr. Charles H. Werner, Mr, and Mrs. Robert A. Van Wyck and Mrs. James B. Hendrick
The Caronia left Gibraltar yesterday on her way to Naples and Alexandria. Sbe is due here on the 19th inst. and returns to New York on the 20th inst, via Rome and Naples.

div.head: STEAMER AGROUND IN CANAL.
div.p: The French steamer America, bound to Jeddab with Algerian pilgrims, is aground in the Suez Canal, near the small lake, since early this morning, and is stopping the traffic. The tog Titan has been despatched to her assistance.
The S.S. Tangistan, which was ashore at Saakin, arrived at Saez this morning, and will go into drydock for repairs

The Italian praiser Marcatonis Cologne has has arrived here and will await the arrival of H.R. H. the Duke of Udins, who is returning from a tour round the world, and is expected early next week. : Last Tuesday, Mr. Black, a young Boglishman who is making stay at Port Said, commenced a 10 days' walk to Cairo and back. Yes. terday, at noon, he was reported to have passed Ismailia, Mr. Black is a good all round sportsman'; he has played for Port Said, and op more than one occasion he has got them out of a difficult at bookey, cricket, and football.

Port Said, Sonday, The commander of the Italian cruiser yesterday paid a visit to the Governor, accompanied by the Italian Consol. In the afternoon the Governor returned the visit. The cruiser left this morning for Suez.

div.head: IMPORTANT FIND AT LUXOR
div.p: Mr. Theodore M. Davis has discovered in the Valley of the Kings the tomb of the great Queen Thi, wife of Amenhotep III. It contains ber mommy, coffin, canopie jars, and numerous other beautiful and interesting objects. The inspirations will be welcomed by all Egyptologists.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive, who came down to Alexandria on Friday night, will spend a few days inspecting his estates at Mariout.
After Kourban Beyram the Khedive intends to go on a trip to the desert.

div.head: K. S. C.
div.p: JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIP POLO
"JOURNAMENT. The cold windy weather, and the absence of a band no doubt accounted for the small gathering assembled to witness these matches on Saturday.
First MATCH E INNISKILLING DRAGOONS 6. K.8.C. Mr. Merriman I. Mr. Spier 1 Mr. Nixon II Capt. Kennedy II. Mr. Holland III. Capt. Hadow III. Mr. Bowen, back. ' Capt. Bartlett back.

The match began tamely, play being slow and rather interesting. In the second chokker was brighter, both sides, however, missing easy shots at goal. In the third chokker Capt. Bartlett, who bad been playing a good game throughout, made a fine ron ap the ground, and Mr. Spier, bo!ding the opposing back, soored a good goal. Soore : K.8.C. I goal to love. Mr. Bowen shortly afterwards equalized. Play now became faster, Capt. Bartlett especially being conspicuous. Capt. Hadow also seemed to find his game at last, and scored a clever goal, bringing the score to 2 to 1 in favour of the K.S.C., and in the last minute Capt. Bartlett added a third.
Final score: K.S.C., 3 goals. Inniskilling Dragoons, 1 goal.
'SECOND MATCH. TIGERS v. COLDSTREAM GUARDS No. I. TEAM. Capt. Sterling I. Mr. Warde Aldom Mr. MacGillivray II. Mr. Beckwith Mr. Jepkinson III. Mr. Gibbs Mr. Reid, back. Mr. Bentinck

These two sides had met twice before in practice games, each side winning a match. This naturally added extra interest to the game. From the throw-in Mr. Jenkinson came away, bat missed his shot, and some give-and take in the middle of the ground followed. In the second chokker the play was keener and faster than ever, Mr. Jenkinson doing great work for his side, bat be missed an easy goal. We noticed a good deal of missing on both sides, but the keenness of all the players made up for this. It was not until the fourth and last chukker that Mr. Beckwith scored a goal for the Guards. This pat K. 8. C. on their metal, Captain Sterling equalizing. Shortly afterwards Mr. Jenkinson added yet another, which brought the score to 2 to 1 in favour of the K. 8. C. Bat the Guards were not done with, and made a most determined attack on the goal of the K. 8. C., who, after saving their goal several times, were at last besten in their detence. This brought the soore to 2 all. Ten seconds later the bell rang, 80 an extra chakker bad to be played. The Guards, who evidently were still fall of fight, soon settled matters, a good run up the ground resulting in a goal. Final scores : Tigers, 2 goals ; Coldstream Guards, 3 goals.
So ended a very keen, hard contested match. The next tie will be played off on Tuesday.

div.head: FAYOUM RACES.
div.p: The first winter meeting of the Fayoum Racing Club will be held at Payoum on Friday next. There are five events on the card, aod entries must be made before Thareday to the hops. secretaries, Mr. R. H. Way or Abmed Efendi Fatbi, Fayoum. The Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior and Lady Victoria Macbell are to be present. Any tourists wishing to attend this op-country meeting should notify one of the hon. secretarie', who will arrange for lanoh and arabias to the course at P.T. 30 a bead.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan came down to Alexandria yesterday from Cairo.

The Khedive has conferred the grade of Mirmiran on Monbeb Bey, Governor of the Haez Canal, and Dr. Mohamed Bey Shukri, both of whom now become Pasb and the Medjidie of the Yad class on De. Almy Pasba.
We regret to announce the death, which took place on Friday night in Cairo, of Youssef Bey Sbawki, Counsellor to the Native Court of Appeal.
The French Government has conferred the Legion of Honour on Count Alexander de Zogheb, the Portuguese Consul in Alexandria.
M. Empain, the Belgian capitalist, who is o largely interested in Egypt, has been made Baron by the King of the Belgians.
Boghor Pasha Nabar is arriving from Eprope on the 15tb inst.
M. Nico'aos Thectokis, son of the Hellenio Premier, left on Saturday for Cairo, and will have an audience of the Khedive.
Lient. Lord A. J. Percy, 3rd Battalion Grenadier Gaarde, has been selected for employment with the Egyptian Army.
Sir Nowell and Lady Salmon will spend the next few weeks in Cairo, where Sir William and Lady East have recently arrived.
We regret that Dean Butcher's condition is still such as to cause considerable anxiety to his many friends.
Col. Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, left yesterday for Cairo.

The following were that passengers by the train deluxe for Upper Egypt on Friday night : Saad Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Education ; Ahmed Effendi Nagaib, Mr. Haar, Mr. 8 Halperin, Mrs. Hayes Saleen, Miss O'Meara, Miss J. O'Mears, M. and Mme Schwein.
Mr. Schafer, of the Shannon, Limited, has arrived in Cairo and is stopping at Shepheard's Hotel.
| Mr. and Mrs. Bland-Satton arrived in London last week from Syria.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice : Major General Ballock, CB, Capt. Danbar, Lieut.-Col. Allfort, Mr. MacMillan and party. div.head: TELEGRAMS.
div.p: CHANNEL TUNNEL.
PREJUDICIAL TO NATIONAL SECURITY!

London, January 12. The "Daily Telegraph '' states that there is reason to believe that the Committee of Imperial Defence, at its last meeting, decided that the construction of a Channel Tunnel would be prejudicial to national security. (Reuter)
CHINESE FAMINE.
NO RELIEF WORKS ORGANISED.

LONDON, January 13. Reuter's Agency learns from Shanghai that the representative of the foreign relief committee for the victims of Tsingkiangpn reports that the refugees in camps number 450,000. Women and children are everywhere to be seen grabbing for roots and grass for food. They are cooking leaves and twigs. No relief works have been organised, though it would be easy to do so. (Reuter)
MR. BIRRELL'S APPOINTMENT.

LONDON, January 12. The statements with reference to Mr. Birrell becoming Mr. Bryoa's successor have revived the Irish question in the Unionist papers, which Assert that Mr. Birrell only accepted the post after the names of other Cabinet Ministers had been submitted to and rejected by Mr. Redmond. (Reuter)
RUSSIA AND PÉRSIA.

ST. PETERSBURG, January 12. Replying to the notification of the Shah's demise, the Tear telegraphed to his successor his condolences and expressed the hope that the Russo-Persian friendship would be still further strengthened. (Reuter)
TRENCH COURTS MARTIAL.
- Paris, January 12. The Council of Ministers has decided to suppress the permanent court martial. (H.)
DEATH OF LORD RUSSELL.
London, January 12. Lord Alexander Russell is dead. (Reuter)
AUSTRIAN VOTING.
VIENNA. January 12., · The Chamber has accepted the Bill on the liberty of voting. (Havas)
WALES BEATS ENGLAND.
LONDON, January 12. Football. Rugby. Wales beat Poland by 92 points to nil. (Reuter)
BELGIAN CONGO MISSION.
ACCOMPANIED BY BRITISH MILITARY MISSION.

BRUSSELS, January 13. The "Petit Blen" announces that a mission of Belgian engineers, together with a British military mission, will start on 31st January. They will travel via Egypt and the Sodar). Their objective will be to survey the railway from Lado to the Congo frontier. (Reuter)
GERMANY AND MOROCCO.
LIEUT. WOLFF'S APPOINTMENT.

BERLIN, January 12. The "Cologne Gazette" states that Lieutenant Wolff has been called Morocco only as ad latus to Major Tschadi and as such his duties will be to assist tha Major in his office of Chief Engineer to the Sultan. Lieutenant Wolff will also find employment in the personal service of the Saltan and will perhaps have some connection with the cavalry. He is an excellent polo player, a game that the Sultan is very fond of. The statement that Lieut. Wolff is going to Morocco as cavalry instructor is untrue. He has nothing whatever to do with the organization of the troops or the police. (Reuter)
KAISER AND HIS ARMY.

BERLIN, January 13. It is stated that the Emperor has taken stringent measures to put down luxurious living amongst army officers. He objects to their expensive wines and liquors and the elaborate ménus of the messes, etc., etc. (R.)
RUSSIAN TERRORISM.
St. PETERSBURG,, January 18. The chief of the police of the province of Daghestan (Asiatic Russia) has been assassinated. (Havas)
PLAGUE AT JEDDAH.
CONSTANTINOPLE, January 12. A case of plague followed by death has been discovered at Jeddah and another case at Smyrna. Five days' quarantine has been imposed. (Havas)
AWA MARU REFLOATED.
LONDON, January 13. The Japanese S.S. Awa Maru has been refloated, and will proceed to Newcastle on Tyne to be dry docked for the carrying out of the necessary repairs. (reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: London, January 4.
The Money Market.

The fall in the value of money which we stated last week would probably occur in January has rapidly taken place. At the end of the year 6 percent was freely paid, but today money is not easy to employ at 4 percent, and for a time at least it promises to range between 3 and 4 per cent. We have already warned our readers that this sudden cheapness of money is not likely to be permanent, in consequence of the demsado from many quarters, where great developments are in progress. If, as appears likely, cheap money continue, at any rare for a short time, the opportunity is not likely to be lost by those who have new issues ready, and are only waiting a favourable moment to launch them on the public.Therefore it is that they may come in a rush and make the period of ease still shorter. The public are not open-mouthed just now, however, and any new enterprise is likely to meet with due orificism, but there is no reason to doubt that first-rate companies would have a good chance. Although gold is not plenty," as the Americans put it, there is money to invest, but the many shrinkages of the last five years have made it all very shy and cautious.

The Bank of England statement this week shows a very marked improvement, both on the previous week and on 1906. The reserve has risen £969,363, which is an increase on last year of no less than £1 839 543; so that there is no ground for any apprehension in the immediate future, so loud as the conservative policy is porened, and the Bank rate is not prematurely lowered.
The Stock Markets.

It is rather early to give an opinion regarding the probable course of the stock markets during 1907, but there is no reason to be disappointed with the movements so far. The opening on Wednesdıy -the "House" was. closed on - New Year's Day- was very satisfactory, and those energetic members who contented themselves with the single day's holiday on Tuesday, and commenced the year at business, had no reason to regret doing so.

Of course, a very important factor inducing to the improved tone was the easing of the monetary position. At the Control settlement the contango was much easier than a month ago, being proud about 51 percent, hence the effect on gilt-edged stock: was very marked. This good influence extended to most other departments, home railways being especially brisk.

Yesterday, with the exception of gilt-edged securities, there was some falling away from the good position assumed at the opening, due, no dogbt, to an extent to profit : taking, and to-day markets opened dullish. This afternoon, bowover, the tone has been better in most sections, though only restricted business: has been done.

As to the future, the monetary position will, of course, play an important part, bot, as we have said before, the present 6 por cont, offi :ial minimum is likely to continue in for cu for some time to come, and a general recognition of this probability will be helpful to those who are relying upon a reduced rate to bring a revival in stock and share dealing.
Consols.

The gilt-edged market has been very favourably affected by the ending of the money position, and there is vestment in advance of a portion of the Control dividende shortly to be distributed. On Wednesday Capsules advanced 2%, and yesterday at the close they were higher cash at 83, the price for the account being to better at 85 after being as high as 87. The closing quotations to night for cash and account are 86 and 87.
Foreign Bonds.

The foreign market opened firm, the strength of Russia being a notable feature. The Fours and the new Fives, each advanced to 78 and 2 discounts. Yesterday the bonds were again, very buoyant, The Four per Cent. Nicholas roce 1, the Fours and the Shorif A Japanese 6 percent. second verio-, were > better at 101..
Today Russia has fallen back to 781, and the new script to discount. Japanese have been active, and several of the stocks have advanced Homo Ralle.

The dividend prospects and castar money conditions more than counterbalanced the adverse or finances of the bad weather and the Scotch disaster, and on Wednesday thin market was quite buoyant. Improvements were shown almost throughout the list, the fatora boeing South Western Deferte, which had a rise of 17. North Eastern were 1 higher, South Eastern Deferred 4. and Great Western and Great Northern.

Yesterday the market roasted somewhat,-and the fone was doll and irregular. Th9 jabatan tial rice in South Western Def tread on the previous day brotigbt in a number of pr fit. takers, and the price, after improving to 551 at the opening, relapsed to 51. North Stof: fordshire roro 1, and Great Northern Deferred and G-eat Western 1. The Scotch stroke was heavy. Caledonian Ordinary dropping & and the Deferred 4. Today, the stocks of the heavies have been offered, bat South Western Deferred have recovered 1).

The traffic) returns for the half year inst ended are now published, and they are very gratifying, more especially when it is remembered that they are compared with substantial Increases in the same period of 1905. The North Eastern have a total increase of £25 8,000,
• Delayed in transmission.

div.head: The Great Western
div.p: The Great Western are $141,800, the L. & N. W. £111,010, and the Lancashire & Yorkshire £92,600, while in three other cases the increases are over £50,000.
Americans

"There has been a great deal of uneasiness in New York regarding the monetary position, and this has naturally been reflected in the movement in American shares, here. Thus, although at the commencement the market was firm with prices well above parity, New York advices caused a set-back. Yesterday the opening was firm, though at a lower level than Wednesday's close, but later in the day the tone again weakened, Unions losing 1 to 184 up Southern Pacifio 17 to 95, and Milwakee, which had finished 2 lower on the previous day, 1.
Americans have been quiet to-day, and the changes are slight.
Egyptians.

For the greater part of the week there has been little movement in the Egyptian market, owing to the celebration of the Christmas holidays in Egypt, and prices have in the main been nominal. It is satisfactory to note that now, however, the tendency is much improved, and the outlook is regarded favourably.

National Bank changed brands as high as 28, then fell to 28 sellers. They close tonight buyers at 281. Agricultural Bank have been firm at 9, the Preference at 9.3, but the latter close 95. Daira Sanieh Ordinary, after being dull at 17 sellers, close buyers at 17, and the Deferrad are 98 100.

Delta Preference are quite staguant at 12, but Delta Land and Investment are better at 4. United Egyptian Land. Defèrred have been in request, and are buyers about 6. Egyptian Estates are very firm at 2, and the Deferred at 21-23, but Corporation of Western Egypt are easier at 7 premium. Egyptian Markets, at about 1, and Balt and Soda, at 23/6, are still unmentioned.
Building Lands of Egypt are buyers at 6, but there seem to be no shares on offer. Khedivial Mail are unchanged at 17 for the Ordinary and 4 for the Preference, and Bank of Romania are steady at 9.
Mining

The South African market on Wednesday was very active, and the shares received much attention both from local and continental buyers. Diamond descriptions were strong. De Beers gaining 1 and Jagersfontein and Premier 1 Bankets were 1 higher.

Yesterday, in common with other sections, the tone was dull, and in most cases the advances of the previous day were lost. De Beers gave way I to 25, and Jagerfontein dropped. Premier, on the other hand, were a good point, and advanced 5 to 13. Banket declined 3, Tangany ks to East Rand 0.25, and Rand Mines 3.
This morning Kaffirs were weak, but later considerable support was given, quotations improving smartly. East Rands put on 5, and Rand Mines 1/8.
Egyptian mining shares are absolutely flat, and there is no movement to report.

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: THE COMPANY has been formed for the purposes stated in the Memorandum of Association, and more particularly to establish a line of British steamships to supply the demand made by the increasing passenger traffic for a first class and rapid service between Europe and Egypt

The Fairfield Shipbuilding and Engineering Company, Limited, of Glasgow, has contracted with the Company for the construction of two turbine steamers of about 13,000, tons gross register, the length of the vessels to be 550 feet and breadth 60 feet. The steamers will each have five turbines, viz: —three turbines for going ahead and two for going astern. They will each have three propellers and (according to specification) are to steam no less than 201 knots an hour, at which speed the passage between Marseilles and Alexandria should be accomplished in 70 hours. Accommodation will be provided for 500 first class and 280 second class passengers.

In preparing the specification for their steamers, the Directors have had in view the recent great advances that have been made in the fitting of steamers with the object of easing the outfort of passengers. Besides state-room accommodation of the most up to date character, a number of "cabineta de loxe," each with private bathroom, etc., adjoining will be provided, and in addition to the usual public room there will be on the upper deck a restaurant (having separate kitchens and service) in which meals will be served at all hours à la carte.

In view of the ports, Matreilles' ' and Alex andria, at which the steamers will call, special attention has been paid to ventilation. This will be affected by the thermotank system by which the air in every part of the ships will be changed six times an hour. Other features will be a children's salon and passenger lift communicating with the various passenger decks. I will be seen that the Company's steamer will reproduce all the most striking features.

div.head: Newest Liners
div.p: Some of the newest Atlantic liners and as regards comfort and speed, will 8: pars anything hitherto attempted by any lines running between Europe and Egypt.
Lord Cromer's Report of the 8th March, 1906, contains the following reference with regard to the passenger traffic with Europe:---

" I have alluded in my recent Annual Reports to the enormous increase which has taken place during the last few years in the passenger traffic between Egypt and Europe. In 1902, 60,000, and in 1903. 171,000 passengers disembarked at Port Said and Alexandria. I. 1904 the total number was 90,410. In 1905 it rose to 99,922. These figures are exclusive to troops, but include all classes of passengers."
The Directors believe that the special facilities which the Company's service will provide will appeal to the largely increasing travelling public and will also prove highly remunerative.

The contract price for the above-mentioned steamers is £6 6,000 payable in the nanal method by instalmente, whereof £106,000 is payable during contraction, leaving £400,000 payable on delivery of the steamers or at the option of the Company by instalments extending over two years.

The Directors will in any event go to allotment, having regard to the fact that the following persons have applied for 40,000 ordinary and 40,000 deferred shares of the Company in the following amounts :

The remaining 26,610 ordinary shares and the whole of the 40,000 deferred share have been allotted to the subscribers or their nominees at par.

div.head: NAVY CONTRACTS.
div.p: PORT SAID AND SUEZ.

TENDERS are hereby invited for now Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables, Soft Bread, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Said and Suez for twelve months from 1st April 1907.
Each article should be tendered for separately, but the tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm must be placed on the same Form.

Prices should be quoted in English on renoy. Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate General, Port Said, to whom tenders should be sentra duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January 1907.
The Admiralty reserves the right of rejecting all or any tudors, and of accepting any portion of a tender.
(Signed) D.A. CAMERʻN,
Mavy, Agent. British Consulate General, Port Said. 121h January 1907.

div.head: L'ÉPARGNE IMMOBILIÈRE
div.p: LIMITED
L'assemblée générale statutaire de "l'Epargne Immobilière Limited" a eu liga samedi après-midi au siège de la Société.
17.993 actions étaient représentées.
Il a été décidé de porter le capital de la Scie'. 800,000 livres par l'émission de 175,000 nouvelles actions de La. 4.
Les pouvoirs les plus é engins ont été con. férés au Conseil d'Administration pour le placement de ces nouvelles actions.
Das renseignements communiqués par le. Conseil d'Administration il résulte que la Société a déjà conclu de très brillantes affaires.
Blle a acheté, en tout premier lieu, 80,000 mètres environ de terrains sis à la pointe de l'île de Djézireh dans des conditions exceptionnellement avantageuse.

Cag terrains sont revendus avec de gran les facilités de paiement ; la Société accorde, en effet, trente ans à ses acheteurs pour se libérer. Le lotissement est à peine achevé et déjà 10 lotá sur 60 ont été vending.

La Société compte avoir achevé la rov est à dans deux mois. Cotte opération, très avantageuse pour les acheteurs, ne l'est pas moins par la Société qui en tirera ng bénéfice que l'on évalue à 150.000 livres.

D'autres achats ont également été con olas par l'Épargne Immobilière dans de très bonnes conditions, la Société payant cas terrains en agtións de la nouvelle émission. Une bonne partie des nouvelles actions a. déjà été placée de cette façon..
LAND INVESTMENT
Le coupon de la Land investment est de 60 P.T. pour les aótions et non de 40, comme cela | a été annoncé.
UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS

On nous informe que les administrateurs de l'United. Egyptian Lands, Ltd, ont exercé samedi leur droit d'option sur les 57 føddans de terraine, situés dans l'Île de Rodah, et ont effectué le premier versement de £ 59,00 eur le prix d'achat. ..

Le terrain est avantageusement situé, avec ane f çıde de 1,500 mètres anr le Nil et en bordure sur toute sa longueur de la route Gouvernementale qui traversa Pile. Le coût total s'élève à un demi million de livres sterling,

Il nous revient que la société - a reçu pla. sieurs offres très rémunératrices pour des lots à bâtir sur son terrain. Ua lotissement de tonte la propriété a été dressé et la société opère. être bientôt: en état de mettre des lots en vente.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE " L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE".
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" part chaque Samedi midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revacy complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publi. cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, eto etc
Abondamment pour une année en Egypte odte 1 L.R. y compris les frais de posts ; poar 'étranger 10 P.T. de port ea sqs.

div.head: The Egyptian Land Investment & Building
div.p: Company, Limited.
CANGUR
The Subscription list will open at the Bank of
Athens at Cairo and Alexandria on MONDAY. the 21st day of JANUARY, 1907, and will close on WEDNESDAY, the 23rd day of JANUARY, 1907.
Capital. . £300,000
Divided into 298,000 Ordinary Shares of $1,ench,
and 40,000 Deferred Shares of 1s, each

The Ordinary Shares are entitled to dividends in priority to the Deferred Shares op to 7 per cent. oat of the profits available for distribution as dividend in each year, and subject thereto and after payment of the Directors' additional remuneration, to 60 percent, of the profits. thereafter available for distribution as dividend in each yəar, the Deferred Shares being entitled to the remainder. In the event of the winding ap of the Company, the Capital paid up or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares will be repaid in priority to that paid np or credited as paid up on the Deferred Shares. Any surplus assets remaining after repayment of the Capital paid ap or credited as paid np. will be divided as to 60 per cent. among the Ordinary Shares and as to the remainder among the Deferred Shares.
The Directors now offer for subscription at 1s. premium 100,000 Ordinary Shares, payable as follows : - 26. per share on Application ; 43. per share on Allotment; (inolading
18. prenom). 58, one month after Allotment. and the balance as required in instalments not exceeding 5s. each, aud' at intel vals of not less than one month,
The premiums will be appropriated towards the payment of the preliminary expenses and the underwriting commission.
Share warrants to bearer will be issued if required, after the shards are fully paid, to original subscribers free of stamp diy.

div.head: 1. PROSPECTUS
div.p: This Company has been formed for the purpose of acquiring and developing London, industrial and other undertakings in Egypt, the Sadan and elsewhere, including the scenarios of land concession, and the development of building estates as set on in its Memorandum of A xojation.
The investment of money in Egyptian pro| perties ir ce the completion of the International | Agreements has led a very satisfactory results,
and the expansion and growth of industrial Enterprise which has now set in, presenta most

layourable opportunities for participating in Turbo further impénding developments on very I promißing conditions.. | The Board of Directors propose to direct their attention more particularly to the purchase and development of building land and its division into plots ar dobhair subsequent leasing or re-sale.

Amongst other- remunerative methods of dealing with properties which may be acquired is the erection of houses and other buildings and the re-sale of them on the instalment system. As is well known, the demand for residential premiere, iu the principal towns of Egypt is far in excess of the supply, and the Directors propose to take op business of the foregoing nature and anticipato a considerable demand from Purchasers on the instalment |system and otherwise.

The value of land in Egypt is shown by the isles which are taking place at constantly ev banced prices, and it is believed that the Board of Directors will be able to obtain, through their intimate local knowledge, exceptional opportunities of securing property. which will greatly increase in value at an early date, quite independent of the development works • which may be undertaken.
|Thu Directors have already received several business propositions, which or some of which they believe to be of a most favourable natare.
The e will come under their consideration after the first general allotment of shares, and as negotiations will then have to be entered into, details cannot now be given.

The Company has secured the services as Managing Director of Mr. Robert Scott of Cairo, late Egyptian Manager of the Gresham Life Assurance Society, Ltd., together with the 30-operation, on the Board of Directors, of tha I. other gentlemen named, all of whom have resided in Egypt for a number of years and who are well in touch with the class of business with which the Company will deal.
The amount fixed by the Articles of A880ciation as the minimum subscription on which the Directors may prooed to allotment is ten percent. of the shares offəred for subscription.

The preliminary expenses are • estimated at £ 3,500 (exclusive of the underwriting commission) * Share Warrants to bearer will be issued if required, after the shares are fully paid, to original subscribers free of stamp duty.
The following information is given to comply with the provisions of th) Companies Act," 1900:

Art. 101. – Eich Director shall ba enti: tled to be paid out of the funds of the Com. pany remuneration for his services at the rate of £200 per annum, with an additional £100 per annum for the Chairman of the Board. The Directors shall also be entitled as additional remuneration to 5 percent of the profits of the Company in each year available for dividend remaining after pay. ment of the 7 per cent. preferential dividend on the Ordinary Shares. All such additional remuneration shall be divided amongst the Directors in such proportions and mander at the Board may determine and in default of determination equally. .

Art. 102. – If any Director shall be called upon to perform extra or special services of Any kind, or to travel or go, or reside out of Egypt for any business or proposes of the Company, he shall be entitled to receive sach extra remuneration as the Board (subject to spy direction given by the Company in General Meeting) shall determine, and the same shall be charged as part of the ordinary working expenses of the Company: .

Art. 103. — The qualification of a Director shall be the holding in his own right alone, and not jointly with any other person, of bears or stock of the Company of the nominal amount of £200, and this qua' fi cation shall be required as wall of the first Directors as of all future Directors. A Director may act before obtaining his qualification, but if not already qualified he shall obtain his qualification within two months after his appointment or in default his office eball be vacated. If a Director at any time after the expiration of two'months from the date of his appointment cease to hold his qualification, the his office shəll be vacated. A person vacating offi:e under this Article shall be incapable of being reappointed a Director until he shall have obtained his qualification

Art. 114. - The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of thôir number to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period of office and niay from time to time remove or dism's, any Managing Director from office and appoint another io his place.
Art. 116. — 'The remuneration of a Mara. ging Director sh»l be fixed by the Directors and may bay by way of salary, commission, participation in profits, or all or any of these u o les.
The Directors are subscribing for and will be allotted in Deferred Sharer
allows :Robert Scott 5,000, Negbib Eid 3,000, Jern Joannides 2,000, Hanri Steidemann 1000, Akhnoukh Papous, 1,000.

The contents of the Memorandum of A380ciation of the Company, with the names, addresses, and descriptions of the signatories, and the number of shares subscribed for by them, is printed in the fold, and forms part of this Prospectus.

The Company has entered into an agreement, dated the fifteenth day of January 1907, with Neighb Eid, under which he underwriter 100.000 Ordinary Shares of the Company in consideration of a cash commission of five per cent.

In addition to the above mentioned underwriting contract 4 contract dated the fifteenth day of January 1907 between the Company and the said Robert Scott has been entered | into the appointment of the latter as Managing Director and providing for his remuneration as such.. | Thy Company will pay a brokerage of three
pence per share on all allotments made on | applications made by the pob ia bearing bro. "kers' or bankers' stamp.

A print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and copies of the above mentioned contract can be seen at the offices of the Company in Cairo and of their Legal adviser in Alexandria daring asgal busi nest hours, at any time before the closing of the subscription list.
By the Article: the Capital can be increased to Lst. 500,000 by a simple resolution of the Board.
Applications for shares should be møde op the accompanying form and be forwarded to the Company's Bankers with a cheque for the amount payable on applica'i in.

If an allotment is not made the application money will be returned in full, and where the tomber of shares allotted is less than tha: applied for, the surplus will be credited towards the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant. Failore
o pay any instalments when doe will render all previous payments liable to forfeiture.
Prospeotages and Application Forms can be obtained at the offices of the Company in Cairo.
and the offi 03 of the Bunkers, in Cairo and Alexandria.
